p: In Europe and North America, as well as in Altai and Russia, the most commonly observed ploidy of A. vulgaris was 2 n = 16 ( x = 8) [ 38], while specimens from the high Himalayas, which underwent a period of glaciation, were found to be mainly diploids having 2 n = 18 chromosomes [ 39]. At different elevations in this same region, examples of tetraploid (2 n = 36) and hexaploid (2 n = 54) were also found [ 39]. However, biotypes from other regions of the world have been reported with chromosome numbers of 2 n = 16, 18, 24, or 36 [ 7].
